oai_dc:dc.dc:title: PREDICTION OF BEACH PROFILE CHANGE AT MESOSCALE UNDER RANDOM WAVES
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Larson, Magnus
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: beach profile
profile change
mesescale
random waves
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A mesoscale model is presented to calculate the average net cross-shore transport rate and beach profile evolution under random waves. Cross-shore transport formulas for random waves are derived by superimposing the transport from individual waves, which belong to an ensemble that represents the random wave field. The transport relationships for individual waves are based on experiments with monochromatic waves in large wave tanks. The model is validated using beach profile data from the SUPERTANK Laboratory Data Collection Project and three different types of profile evolution events are studied, namely equilibrium erosion with bar formation, berm flooding, and the impact of breaking waves on an offshore mound. Berm flooding includes the erosion of a well-developed summer berm and the erosion of an artificially constructed foredune, and the offshore mound tests encompass narrow- and broad-crested mounds.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 24 (1994): Proceedings of 24th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Kobe, Japan, 1994.
